The instructor also points out the difference between freestyle and folkstyle wrestling in terms of how you can hold the opponent once you've landed in this defensive position. In freestyle, you have two points for control, whereas in folkstyle, you can simply hold the arm and maintain the position.

Overall, this technique is all about timing and anticipation, ensuring that you can defend against the pop-up single leg and potentially reverse the situation to your advantage.

As the skier takes to the trampoline, we see them executing a series of preparatory movements to get a feel for the shifty. The next step involves placing their hands straight in front of them and looking forward at the end of the tramp. This is crucial for maintaining balance and control during the jump. Tip number three is about the follow-through. Many players have a short follow-through, which can lead to inconsistent shots. You want to make sure you have a full follow-through. As you swing up and make contact with the ball, continue to swing through the shot. Your racket should end up on the opposite side of your body. This will help you generate more power and control in your forehand.

Remember, practice these tips regularly to improve your forehand technique. Keep swinging low to high, keep your racket face closed, and always follow through completely. With consistent practice, you'll see significant improvement in your game.

Now, let's talk about the follow-through. Many players think that the follow-through is just a natural part of the swing and doesn't really affect the shot. But the truth is, the follow-through is crucial for maintaining balance and control. When you hit the ball, your body is moving forward, and you need to decelerate that movement to avoid overextending and losing balance. The follow-through helps you do that.

Notice how I'm keeping my racket arm extended and my non-dominant arm is guiding the racket through the finish. This helps me maintain control and ensures that I don't over-swing. The follow-through should be smooth and controlled, not jerky or abrupt. It's like you're drawing a line with your racket from the point of contact all the way through to the finish.

Another important aspect of the follow-through is the direction it takes. You want your racket to finish in the direction you want the ball to go. If you're hitting a cross-court forehand, your racket should finish on your left side (if you're right-handed). If you're hitting a down-the-line forehand, your racket should finish on your right side. This helps you maintain accuracy and control.

He uses his own legs to pin down the opponent's legs, creating a stable base for further attacks. From this position, he can apply pressure to the opponent's body, making it difficult for them to escape or counterattack.

The next step is to transition into a banana split. This involves spreading the opponent's legs wide apart, causing discomfort and potentially leading to a submission. The instructor shows how to use his body weight to apply pressure on the opponent's legs, making it difficult for them to close their legs or move.

Finally, the instructor demonstrates how to set up a wrestler's guillotine from the leg ride position. He wraps his arm around the opponent's neck, applying pressure to the throat and cutting off blood flow to the brain. This can lead to a quick submission if the opponent doesn't tap out in time.

As the video progresses, we see Yuri Simoes demonstrating a seamless transition from the body x-guard position to side control. He begins by releasing his grip on one leg and reaching for the other with his hand, passing it behind his knee. This movement is fluid and calculated, showing the precision required in jiu-jitsu.

Yuri then switches the leg over his knee, using his knee to push the opponent's leg away, almost like a leg drag. This technique is crucial for creating space and disrupting the opponent's base, making it easier to advance to the next position.

With the leg now passed, Yuri pushes and reaches, applying pressure on the opponent's arm. This is a strategic move, as he uses the arm to apply leverage and gain an advantageous position.

Finally, Yuri gets up and starts passing to the side, maintaining pressure on the opponent's arm throughout. His movements are efficient and demonstrate a high level of skill and control, showcasing the effectiveness of this body x-guard sweep to side control technique.

The skier lands smoothly on the mat, demonstrating excellent control and technique. Remember, practice is key to mastering these moves. Start with small jumps and gradually increase the height and complexity as you become more comfortable with the movements.

Now, let's talk about the follow-through. Many players think that they need to finish high with their racket after hitting the ball. But what you really want to do is finish low. Yes, you read that right, finish low. When you finish low, you're allowing the racket to naturally come down and across your body, which helps to generate more topspin on the ball. And remember, topspin is your friend when it comes to controlling the ball and keeping it in play.

Another important aspect of the forehand is footwork. You want to make sure you're stepping into the shot with your front foot, transferring your weight from back to front. This not only helps with power but also with balance and stability. And don't forget to pivot on your back foot as you swing through the ball. This will help you generate more rotation and control.

Finally, practice, practice, practice. The forehand is a skill that takes time and repetition to master. So get out there on the court and work on these tips. As we continue to explore the intricacies of boxing's most impactful body shots, let's focus on the technique and execution of these powerful punches. The liver shot, as previously mentioned, is a devastating blow aimed at your opponent's liver, located just below the floating ribs on the right side of their body. When throwing this punch, it's crucial to step offline slightly to avoid being caught in a straight line with your opponent's defense. Your weight should shift onto your lead leg, and you should dip down to generate maximum power.

The spleen shot, on the other hand, targets the spleen, situated under the floating rib on the left side of the body. This punch can cause significant internal damage and is known for its ability to incapacitate an opponent quickly. Remember, the key to delivering a successful spleen shot is to use your right hand if you're in an orthodox stance, stepping offline and transferring your weight effectively.

When practicing these shots, it's essential to visualize your opponent and aim for the correct anatomical target. The liver shot is thrown with your left hand, and the spleen shot with your right, making it easier to remember which side to target. Always ensure you're in a balanced stance and that your body rotation and weight transfer are synchronized

Now, let's talk about tip number four. When you're hitting the ball with a closed racket face, you might start to hit the ball in the net because you're not generating enough power. So, what do you do? You need to generate more power by using your legs and your core. Remember, the power comes from the ground up. So, when you're preparing to hit the ball, make sure you're using your legs to generate that power. You can do this by bending your knees and pushing off the ground as you swing forward. This will help you generate more power and lift on your shots, which will prevent you from hitting the ball in the net.

Another important thing to remember is to keep your eye on the ball. This might seem obvious, but it's crucial for making good contact with the ball. Keep your eye on the ball all the way through the swing, even after you've made contact. This will help you maintain control and accuracy on your shots.

Alright, so we see O'Connell executing this arm drag. He's got a firm grip on his opponent's wrist and is pulling him in close. The key here is the timing and the angle of the pull. Now, let's talk about tip number four. Many players have a problem with their racket face being open at the point of contact. This can lead to a loss of control and power in your shots. To avoid this, you want to make sure that your racket face is closed or neutral at the point of contact. This means that the strings are facing the target, and the racket is not tilted up or down.

To achieve this, you can try practicing with a mirror or a video camera to check your racket face position. You can also work on your grip and wrist position to ensure that the racket face is in the correct position.

Another important aspect of the forehand technique is the follow-through. After making contact with the ball, you want to continue your swing and finish with a smooth follow-through. This helps to generate power and control in your shots.

Remember, practice makes perfect. Keep working on your technique and you'll see improvement over time.

Now, let's talk about tip number two. It's all about the grip. You see, when you're playing tennis, you have to be able to control the racket head. And if you don't have a good grip, you're not going to be able to control the racket head. Now, there are three grips that are commonly used for the forehand: the Eastern, the Semi-Western, and the Western. The Eastern grip is the most common grip used by professional players. It allows for the most control and power. The Semi-Western grip is a little bit more aggressive, and the Western grip is even more aggressive than that. But for most recreational players, the Eastern grip is the best choice. It allows for a good balance of control and power. So, make sure you're using the right grip for your forehand. It will make a big difference in your game.

Alright, so I've got my target set up. I'm going to start shooting these loads and see how they perform. I'll be taking notes on the accuracy and any issues that arise with the handgun. Let's get started.

Okay, so I've shot all five rounds of each load and here are my results. The 6-grain load was a bit low and to the left. The 6.2-grain load was closer to center but still a bit low. The 6.4-grain load was right on target, dead center. The 6.6-grain load was a bit high and to the right. And the 6.8-grain load was way high and to the right. So, it looks like the 6.4-grain load is the winner for this particular handgun and bullet combination.

As for the issue with the first round nosediving into the chamber, it didn't happen with any of the loads I tested today. So, maybe it was just a fluke or maybe the different bullet design helped prevent it from happening.

Overall, I'm happy with the performance of my Taurus PT 1911 and the CFE pistol powder with the 230-grain spear bullets.

Alright, let's break down this Kung Fu combo a bit further. The back fist is a powerful and quick strike that can be used to catch an opponent off guard. It's important to generate power from the hips and core, not just the arm, for maximum impact. After the back fist, the grab and trap motion is crucial for controlling your opponent's movement and creating an opening for the next strike.

The twisting punch, or Yum Top as Sifu Cuddle mentioned, is a rotational punch that uses the body's momentum to deliver a strong hit to the stomach area. This punch requires good footwork and body rotation to generate the necessary force.

Remember, the key to executing this combination effectively is fluidity and timing. The movements should flow seamlessly from one to the next, and you should always be aware of your opponent's positioning and reactions. Practice this combo slowly at first, focusing on proper technique, and then gradually increase your speed as you become more comfortable with the movements.

The video continues with the rider demonstrating the leg yield exercise, which is a fundamental movement in dressage. The rider guides the horse to move sideways away from the leg pressure while maintaining a straight line forward. This exercise helps improve the horse's responsiveness to the rider's leg aids and enhances its lateral flexibility.

The rider emphasizes the importance of symmetry and equal contact on both reins during the leg yield. They also highlight the need for the horse to be forward and willing to move sideways from the leg aid. The rider adjusts their aids to ensure the horse moves smoothly and evenly across the arena.

The video then transitions to the shoulder-in exercise, where the rider positions the horse's body slightly off the track, with the shoulders coming in towards the center of the arena. The rider maintains a steady contact on both reins and ensures the horse is straight and symmetrical in its movement.

The rider explains that achieving self-carriage is crucial at the medium level, and it starts with teaching the horse to stop without relying on the reins. This is an essential step in developing the horse's ability to carry itself independently and maintain balance and control without constant rein support.

Throughout the video, the rider provides clear instructions and demonstrates the exercises effectively, making it an informative and educational resource for dressage riders looking

As we progress through this video, we're going to see the instructor demonstrating various leg rides and transitions into different submission holds. The focus is on the technique and execution of these moves, which are fundamental in catch wrestling.

The instructor starts by explaining the importance of leg rides and how they can be used to control an opponent's legs and hips. He demonstrates a basic leg ride position, where he places his foot on the opponent's hip and uses his other leg to control the opponent's leg. This position allows him to maintain control while looking for opportunities to attack with submissions.

From the leg ride position, the instructor transitions into a banana split, a move that involves spreading the opponent's legs wide apart, causing discomfort and potential injury if not executed properly. He then moves into a wrestler's guillotine, a chokehold that targets the neck and can be applied from various positions.

Throughout the video, the instructor emphasizes the importance of proper technique and body positioning. He also highlights the need for good conditioning and strength to execute these moves effectively.

Overall, this video provides valuable insights into the techniques and strategies involved in catch wrestling, particularly in the use of leg rides and transitions into submission holds. It serves as a great resource for anyone interested in learning more about this style of wrestling

Now, let's talk about tip number four. Many players have a problem with their racket face being open at the low point of the backswing. This can lead to hitting the ball in the net or sending it long. To fix this, you want to make sure your racket face is closed at the low point of the backswing. This means that the racket is tilted down slightly. As you swing up, the racket will naturally become vertical, giving you safe net clearance and preventing the ball from going long.

Tip number five is about making contact with the equator of the ball. You want to hit the imaginary line around the center of the ball, not above or below it. This ensures that you're generating topspin without driving the ball into the net or sending it long.

Finally, tip number six is about keeping the racket vertical through the contact area. Don't think about rolling over the forearm and wrist during contact. Instead, keep the racket vertical for at least half a foot to a foot after contact, then let your wrist and forearm relax as you finish. This helps maintain control and consistency in your shots.

Remember, when practicing, focus on one or two points at a time. For example, focus on getting the racket a foot below the ball before swinging

Alright, so now we're moving on to the leg press. This is a great exercise for your quads, but also hits your glutes and hamstrings as well. You want to make sure you have a medium stance, shoulder-width apart, and you want to make sure that you're pushing through your heels. Don't put too much pressure on the balls of your feet because you want to make sure you're getting full stimulation on the quads. And when you come up, you want to make sure you're squeezing at the top. And again, control the motion. Don't just let the weight come back down on you. You want to make sure you're controlling it all the way through. And you want to make sure you're breathing properly. Fill your diaphragm up with air on the way down, breathe out on the way up. And definitely, this is one of the best exercises for your lower body. And that's Biggie's tip of the day.

Alright, let's continue with the video. As we see, the instructor is demonstrating a series of defensive techniques against a single leg takedown. He starts by controlling his opponent's posture, keeping his head down and pushing it towards the ground. This is a crucial step in preventing the takedown as it disrupts the attacker's balance and momentum.

Next, he switches his hands from the opponent's upper body to his triceps, pulling them towards himself while stepping forward and kicking his foot to the floor. This maneuver helps in creating distance and destabilizing the attacker's grip on the leg.

If the initial defense doesn't work, the instructor suggests switching to a whizzer grip, which involves taking the hand closest to the opponent's back and bringing it inside. From here, he twists his knee down and frames off the opponent's head, eventually slipping his leg out and transitioning into a front headlock. This position allows for various submission attempts or further defensive maneuvers.

The instructor also emphasizes the importance of adapting to different scenarios and opponents' skill levels. He demonstrates how to switch between grips and techniques seamlessly, always looking for opportunities to counterattack or escape.

Throughout the video, the instructor provides detailed explanations and demonstrations, making sure to highlight key points and common mistakes to avoid.

As we continue with Harald Harb's "How to ski" series, Lesson 3 delves deeper into the intricacies of executing advanced parallel turns. Harald emphasizes the importance of mastering the fundamental movements that initiate these turns. He explains that the tipping action of the ski begins with the foot and ankle inside the boot, which then translates to the leg. This movement is crucial for skiers to understand as it sets the foundation for a smooth and controlled turn.

Harald demonstrates this by showing how tipping the right foot towards the little toe edge causes the ski to go onto the edge, followed by the knee. He clarifies that the knee movement is a result of the foot and ankle action, not the cause. This distinction is vital for skiers to grasp as it helps them avoid common mistakes such as pushing the knee out excessively.

He further illustrates this concept by performing the movement at a direct angle, highlighting the lightening of the ski as it tips onto the edge. The key takeaway here is that the skier should not press the ski down but rather lighten it, allowing the ski to make the curve naturally. This subtle yet powerful technique ensures that the skier stays balanced over their skis throughout the turn.

Alright, so we're looking at this mini ramp and it's clear that something is off. The coping, which is the metal edge on top of the ramp, is missing. Without it, the edge is rough and uneven, making it difficult and potentially dangerous for skaters to perform tricks.

The skater in the video is attempting to navigate this obstacle, but it's evident that the lack of coping is causing issues. He's trying to do a kickflip, a trick where the skateboard flips 360 degrees along its axis, but the rough edge is affecting his board's movement. It's not just about the trick itself; it's also about the safety concerns. Skating on an edge without coping can lead to accidents and injuries.

As we move into the next part of the workout, we have a series of exercises that are designed to challenge both strength and endurance. After completing the 2K row, participants will transition into a series of movements that include squat to stands, hollow holds, and single-leg bridges.

The squat to stand movement is a great way to engage the lower body, particularly the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It's important to maintain proper form throughout this exercise, keeping your back straight and your core engaged as you alternate between the squatting position and standing up.

Following the squat to stands, the hollow hold is an isometric exercise that targets the core muscles. Lying on the ground with feet together and shoulder blades off the ground, participants must hold this position for the specified time. This exercise helps improve stability and control, which are essential for overall athletic performance.

Finally, the single-leg bridge is a unilateral exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. By lifting one leg off the ground and supporting the body with the other, participants can strengthen their lower body while also improving balance and coordination.

Alright, now we're moving on to the next exercise which is a lunge. You want to start with your feet together, take a big step forward with one foot, and then lower yourself down into a lunge position. Make sure your front knee is directly over your ankle and your back knee is almost touching the ground. From here, you're going to push through your front heel to return to the starting position. Alternate legs with each rep. Remember to keep your core tight and your upper body upright. You'll do 15 reps on each leg.

Next up, we have a plank. Get into a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders and your feet hip-width apart. Engage your core and hold this position for as long as you can. If you need to, you can lower onto your forearms. The goal is to maintain a straight line from head to heels without sagging or lifting your hips. Hold for 30 seconds to start and increase the time as you build strength and endurance.

Now it's time for some mountain climbers. Start in a high plank position again. Bring one knee up towards your chest and then switch to the other knee, mimicking the motion of running. Keep your core engaged and your movements quick.

As we watch the video, we see a group of cyclists tackling a climb. The rider in the blue jersey is demonstrating excellent technique by staying seated and pedaling at a steady cadence. This is an efficient way to conserve energy while climbing, as it allows the rider to use their leg muscles more effectively and maintain a consistent power output.

Notice how the rider's body position is slightly leaned forward, with their weight distributed evenly over the pedals. This helps to maintain traction and stability on the bike, especially on steeper sections of the climb.

As the climb gets steeper, the rider in the black jersey stands up out of the saddle. This is a common technique used when the gradient increases and requires more power to overcome gravity. By standing, the rider can generate more force through their legs and push the pedals down with greater momentum.

It's important to note that standing up should be done in short bursts, as it is less efficient than sitting and can lead to fatigue if done for too long. The rider should alternate between sitting and standing, using the most effective technique for the specific section of the climb they are on.

Welcome to our video on "The Liver Shot and Spleen Shot | Boxings BIGGEST Body Punches". Today, we're going to explore two of the most powerful and feared punches in boxing: the liver shot and the spleen shot.

First up, we have the liver shot. This punch is aimed at the liver, which is located on the right side of the body. When executed correctly, a liver shot can cause immense pain and even knock a fighter out. The key to delivering a successful liver shot is to target the area just below the ribcage and slightly to the right. It's important to note that this punch requires precision and timing, as hitting the liver too high or too low can result in a less effective blow.

Next, we have the spleen shot. This punch targets the spleen, which is located on the left side of the body. Similar to the liver shot, a well-placed spleen shot can be devastating to an opponent. The spleen is a sensitive organ, and a hard punch to this area can cause significant discomfort and potentially lead to a knockout. To deliver a spleen shot, aim for the area just below the ribcage and slightly to the left.

The rider is now demonstrating the leg yield exercise, which is a fundamental movement in dressage. The horse is being guided to move sideways away from the rider's leg pressure while maintaining a straight line with its head and body. This exercise helps improve the horse's responsiveness to the rider's aids and enhances its lateral flexibility.

As the rider executes the leg yield, she is also ensuring that the horse maintains equal contact on both reins and moves willingly from her leg. She is making adjustments to her aids based on the horse's response, such as softening her left rein if the horse is blocking there. This shows the importance of communication and trust between the horse and rider during training.

The instructor is demonstrating a technique for escaping the back control position in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. He starts by explaining that when someone has their arms wrapped around your neck and elbows down, it can be difficult to separate the elbow and go for a knee on belly or north-south position. The instructor suggests putting your biceps on the opposite elbow of the person controlling you, which creates a gap and allows you to move your arm in that direction. He then demonstrates how to lock your arm and switch your hips to pull the other elbow up, giving you the opportunity to attack the arm or go for a choke. The instructor emphasizes the importance of using your weight and driving forward with your shoulder to create pressure and force the person to open up.

Alright, so we have our spider guard set up. Notice how I have one hook on the knee and the other foot is placed on the hip. This positioning allows for maximum control and leverage.

Now, as my partner attempts to pass the guard, I'm going to use my legs to create space and prevent him from getting too close. It's important to keep your feet active and engaged at all times.

As he leans in, I'm going to use my legs to push him away while simultaneously pulling his head down with my arm. This motion creates an imbalance, making it difficult for him to maintain his position.

Once I've created enough space, I'm going to swing my legs over and around, using momentum to sweep him off his base. It's crucial to keep your hips low and your body tight during this movement.

And there you have it, a quick and effective sweep from spider guard. Remember to always practice these techniques with a partner and focus on proper execution. Thanks for watching, and we'll see you in the next video!

As we continue through this video, we see the skier demonstrating the Tony and Octo grabs. The Tony grab is a variation of the mute grab where the skier grabs the toe edge of the ski with their opposite hand while keeping their thumb on top of the ski. This grab adds a bit of flair to the basic mute and can be used in various tricks.

The Octo grab, on the other hand, is a more advanced tweak where the skier grabs both the toe and tail edges of the ski simultaneously with one hand. This grab requires precise timing and control, making it a stylish addition to any skier's repertoire.

The skier in the video is executing these grabs with great form and control, showcasing the importance of practice and repetition in mastering these techniques. The trampoline setup allows for continuous jumps, providing ample opportunity to refine and perfect each grab.

Remember, the key to nailing these grabs is to focus on your body position, hand placement, and timing. With consistent practice and patience, you can add these stylish tweaks to your skiing arsenal and elevate your freestyle game.

Now, if he does manage to get inside and grab my leg, what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna try to pull my leg back and up, and then I'm gonna try to kick him off of me. And if that doesn't work, I can always try to sprawl out and use my other leg to push him away.

So, the key to stopping the single leg takedown is to control your opponent's posture, connect your hands, and use your legs to defend against the takedown. And if all else fails, you can always try to sprawl out and use your other leg to push him away.

As we continue through this video, we're going to see a progression of techniques that build upon the initial leg ride position. The instructor is demonstrating how to transition from a basic leg ride into more advanced submissions like the banana split and wrestler's guillotine.

The instructor starts by establishing a strong base with his leg over the opponent's, controlling the space and preventing the opponent from sitting back or escaping. He then proceeds to secure a grip on the opponent's foot, which is crucial for executing the ball and chain submission. This involves wrapping the leg around the opponent's ankle and applying pressure to the Achilles tendon, making it difficult for the opponent to move or defend.

Once the ball and chain is in place, the instructor demonstrates how to adjust the position to create space for the banana split submission. This involves driving the opponent's hips back while maintaining control of the foot, causing discomfort and potentially leading to a submission.

In this segment of the "Rider Biomechanics Certification Programme," we see a person demonstrating the correct positioning of the seat bones and how it affects the rider's posture. The individual is holding a small model of a horse and rider to illustrate the points being made.

As we continue to watch this video, we see the individual demonstrating the technique for delivering a liver shot and spleen shot. The liver shot is executed with the left hand, aiming for the area just below the opponent's right rib cage, while the spleen shot is delivered with the right hand, targeting the corresponding spot on the left side. These punches are particularly effective because they target vital organs that, when struck, can cause significant discomfort and potentially incapacitate an opponent.

The liver shot, when landed correctly, can result in the opponent losing their breath momentarily, often described as feeling like all the air has been expelled from their lungs. This can leave them vulnerable and disoriented, providing an opportunity for a follow-up attack or to end the fight.

On the other hand, the spleen shot can cause internal damage, potentially leading to more severe consequences such as bruising of the spleen or even a rupture, which can result in symptoms like blood in the urine. This type of injury requires immediate medical attention and can have long-lasting effects on the athlete's health.

It's important to note that these shots should only be practiced under the supervision of a qualified instructor and with proper protective gear to minimize the risk of injury during training. The video serves as an educational tool for

This is a great example of how technique and strategy can trump raw strength in grappling.

As we continue with Mo Farah's core workout routine, we see him transitioning to another exercise that targets the lower abs and hip flexors. He's lying on his back with his feet elevated and resting on a stability ball. This position requires significant core engagement to maintain balance and control.

Mo is performing leg raises, lifting his legs up towards the ceiling and then lowering them back down without letting his feet touch the ground. This movement is excellent for strengthening the lower abdominal muscles, which are crucial for maintaining good posture and stability during running.

The key to this exercise is to keep your lower back pressed into the floor and to raise your legs slowly and controlled. It's important not to swing or use momentum, as this reduces the effectiveness of the exercise. Mo demonstrates perfect form, showing us how it's done with precision and control.

Remember, consistency is key when it comes to building a strong core. These exercises should be incorporated into your routine regularly to see noticeable improvements in your running performance and overall athletic ability.

As the video progresses, we see the defensive wrestler executing the technique described. He's on his knees, facing his opponent who is attempting a single-leg takedown. The defensive wrestler quickly reacts by isolating his opponent's foot and using his hands to crawl towards the leg that his opponent has isolated. By doing this, he aims to get his hips perpendicular to his opponent's shoulder, creating an advantageous position for him to counter the takedown.

The defensive wrestler demonstrates the importance of timing and speed in wrestling moves. By anticipating his opponent's actions and moving swiftly to counter them, he can potentially turn the tables and gain control of the situation. This technique showcases the defensive wrestler's ability to think on his feet and adapt to the ever-changing dynamics of a wrestling match.

The video emphasizes the concept of "getting to the next position faster" as a key strategy in wrestling. Alright, let's get started! We're going to begin with some leg swings. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and swing one leg forward and backward, keeping it straight. Now switch to the other leg. This helps loosen up your hip flexors and gets your legs ready for movement.

Next, we'll move on to some arm circles. Hold your arms straight out to the sides and make small circles with your hands. Start with small circles and gradually increase the size. This helps warm up your shoulders and upper back.

Now let's do some torso twists. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and twist your torso from side to side, keeping your arms extended. This helps loosen up your lower back and improves your range of motion.

We'll finish up with some neck stretches. Slowly tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. Hold for a few seconds and then switch to the other side. This helps relieve tension in your neck and shoulders.

Remember to breathe deeply and smoothly throughout this routine. It's important to get your blood flowing and your muscles warmed up before you start your exercise. Happy mobilising, Swifties!

The video continues with a demonstration of the HMS belaying technique, focusing on the correct way to form the knot and secure the rope using a carabiner. The person in the video is seen holding the rope and manipulating it to create the half-mast throw, ensuring that the knot is properly formed and the brake cable runs along the healthy shank of the carabiner. The video emphasizes the importance of checking the knot's integrity and the correct positioning of the brake cable to prevent accidental opening of the carabiner due to rope friction.

The video then transitions to show two different brake positions for belaying with the HMS technique. The first position is with the brake hand above the carabiner, where the brake hand pulls the rope straight up from the carabiner while the guide hand lets the rope run into the carabiner. The second position is with the brake hand below the carabiner, where the brake hand pulls the rope out of the carabiner in a forward movement while the guide hand pulls the rope into the carabiner. The video stresses the importance of maintaining control over the brake rope at all times and ensuring that the brake hand is always closed, not fully opened, to be able to grab it immediately in case of a fall.

The video continues to demonstrate the application of the 2016 Tackle and Breakdown Law Trial in New Zealand domestic rugby competitions. We see players from two teams, one in orange jerseys and the other in maroon, engaging in a breakdown situation on the field.

The scene opens with a player in an orange jersey being tackled by a player in maroon. The tackle is executed correctly, with the tackler bringing the ball carrier to the ground while ensuring they remain on their feet. The ball carrier releases the ball immediately, as required by the law, allowing for open play to continue.

As the breakdown commences, we observe that at least one player from the attacking team (orange) is on their feet over the ball, which is now on the ground. This marks the beginning of the breakdown phase. Only players acting as halfbacks, who are not part of the breakdown and are behind the hindmost foot, can play the ball with their hands. They must be on their feet and onside, and they have the option to run, pass, or kick the ball.

The tackle assist, who is the player assisting in the tackle, must release once the tackle occurs. This ensures that the game remains fluid and that players are not held back unnecessarily.

Now, let's talk about tip number four. Many players have a problem with their racket face being open at the point of contact. This can lead to a loss of control and power in your shots. To avoid this, make sure that your racket face is closed or neutral at the point of contact. This means that the strings should be facing the direction you want the ball to go, not up towards the sky or down towards the ground.

Tip number five is about footwork. Good footwork is essential for getting into position to hit a good forehand. Make sure you're moving quickly and efficiently to get to the ball, and use small, quick steps to adjust your position as needed. This will help you maintain balance and control throughout your shot.

Finally, tip number six is about follow-through. A proper follow-through is crucial for generating power and accuracy in your forehand. After making contact with the ball, continue to swing your racket through the shot, keeping your eyes on the ball until it lands. This will help you maintain a smooth, fluid motion and ensure that you're hitting the ball with maximum force.

By following these tips, you can improve your tennis forehand technique and become a more effective player on the court. Remember to practice regularly and focus on

Absolutely, let's dive into the technique. As the instructor demonstrates, when your opponent throws a jab, you're going to slide to the 5 o'clock position. This is a defensive maneuver that allows you to avoid the incoming punch while maintaining a strong counter-attacking position. The key here is footwork and timing. You want to slide smoothly to the side, keeping your body in line with your opponent's center, so you can quickly respond with a counterattack. Remember, the goal is not just to defend but to set up your next move. Keep your eyes on your opponent and be ready to strike back as soon as you've evaded the jab.

As we continue with the neuromuscular training, you can see the focus on maintaining a consistent and controlled motion. The individual performing the seated runs is demonstrating excellent form by keeping their elbows at a 90-degree angle and their legs straight as they lift their hips using their hip flexors. This type of training is crucial for building quick twitch muscles, which are essential for explosive movements in sports and other high-intensity activities.

As we continue with the video, we see Catherine Haddad-Staller riding an eight-year-old horse in a spacious outdoor arena at the USET headquarters in Gladstone, New Jersey. The setting is serene with trees surrounding the arena, providing a natural backdrop to the training session.

Catherine begins by demonstrating her go-to medium level workout, which she explains is designed to build on the foundational skills introduced in the beginner level. She emphasizes the importance of teaching the rider how to sit and follow the horse's natural motion, as well as mastering turns and leg yields.

The focus shifts to the horse's development, where Catherine outlines her approach to training young horses. She stresses the need to teach them to follow the rider's seat, move away from leg cues, respond to the spur, and establish a straight connection to the hand. These principles form the groundwork for the horse's future training and are essential for building trust and communication between horse and rider.

Catherine also touches on addressing symmetry issues, a common challenge in dressage training. She explains that some horses may require only one ride to correct these issues, while others may take months. Leg yielding is highlighted as a key exercise for improving symmetry, particularly beneficial for medium-level horses.

The video continues with a demonstration of the HMS belay technique, also known as the half-mast throw. The person in the video is using a green rope and a silver HMS carabiner. They start by forming a loop with the rope coming from the climber, creating a U shape. They then place their left index finger into the U of the loop and lead the rope around the back, bringing it over the fingertips. This creates a finished half-mast throw in their hand.

The person then removes their finger and inserts the carabiner into the loop where the finger was placed. They ensure that the brake cable runs along the healthy shank of the carabiner to prevent accidental opening due to rope friction. The knot is checked for turning, indicating that it is correctly tied.

As the video progresses, we see the instructor demonstrating a technique where he uses his right stick to bait his partner's right stick. The partner, anticipating an attack, swings their stick in an angle two position, which is a defensive posture in Modern Arnis. The instructor then skillfully redirects the partner's stick using his left hand while maintaining control of his own stick with his right hand. This demonstrates the concept of "same side bait," where the instructor uses his right stick to draw the partner's attention and commitment to that side, allowing for a counterattack or control from the opposite side.

The fluidity and precision of the movements highlight the importance of timing and positioning in Modern Arnis stick grappling. The instructor's ability to smoothly transition from the bait to the control phase showcases the effectiveness of this technique in neutralizing an opponent's attack. The video serves as an excellent instructional tool for students looking to improve their stick grappling skills in Modern Arnis.

Alright, so we're going to continue with our stick curriculum. We've worked on the flow drills and the stick clinches, now we're going to focus on disarms. Disarming is a crucial skill in Krav Maga, especially when dealing with an opponent who has a weapon. The key to a successful disarm is timing and leverage. We're going to work on a few different techniques to take away the stick from our opponent.

First, we'll start with a basic disarm technique. I'll demonstrate how to grab the stick and use my body weight to pull it away from my opponent. It's important to maintain control of the stick once you have it, so we'll also work on securing the stick and creating distance.

Next, we'll move on to more advanced disarming techniques. These will involve using angles and leverage to our advantage. We'll work on creating an angle by stepping around our opponent and using our body to pin them against the wall. From there, we can use our hands to grab the stick and pull it away.

As we continue with Harald Harb's "How to ski" series, Lesson 3 delves deeper into the intricacies of executing advanced parallel turns. Harald emphasizes the importance of mastering the tipping action of the ski, which is initiated by the foot and ankle inside the ski boot. He demonstrates how this movement translates through the leg, creating a pivotal action that leads to the ski turning on its edge.

Harald clarifies a common misconception in skiing technique, where many believe the knee is the primary driver of the turn. Instead, he highlights that the key lies in the subtle yet powerful movements of the foot and ankle. This nuanced approach not only enhances control but also ensures a smoother, more efficient turn.

Now, let's talk about the technique for delivering these powerful body shots. When you're preparing to throw a liver shot or a spleen shot, it's crucial to maintain proper footwork and balance. You want to pivot on your back foot and transfer your weight into the punch as you step forward with your lead foot. This will give you the maximum power and leverage.

Remember, the key to a successful body shot is not just in the punching motion but also in the setup. You need to create an opening by feinting or throwing other punches to distract your opponent and make them lower their guard. Timing is everything, so you should look for opportunities when your opponent is off-balance or has just thrown a punch.

It's also important to protect yourself after throwing a body shot. Your opponent may be momentarily stunned, but they can still react quickly and counterattack. Keep your hands up and be ready to defend yourself.

Lastly, practice makes perfect. These shots require precision and accuracy, so spend time in the gym working on your technique and timing. Shadowboxing, sparring, and hitting the heavy bag are all great ways to improve your skills.

As we continue to analyze John John Florence's technique, we see him maintaining a low center of gravity as he stands up on the board. This is crucial for stability and control, especially when dealing with the steep and powerful waves like the one he's riding. Notice how his knees are bent, and his body is almost parallel to the wave face. This position allows him to absorb the impact of the wave and make quick adjustments as needed.

John's arms are outstretched for balance, and his eyes are focused on the direction he wants to go. This is important because it helps him anticipate the wave's movements and react accordingly. His weight distribution is also key; he shifts his weight from the front foot to the back foot as he maneuvers the board, which helps him maintain speed and direction.

The way John carves through the wave is another aspect worth noting. He makes smooth, flowing turns that allow him to ride along the wave's face without losing momentum. This is achieved by shifting his weight and using his body to steer the board, rather than relying solely on the rails of the board.

Overall, John John Florence's ability to read the wave, maintain balance, and execute precise maneuvers is what sets him apart as one of the best surfers in the world.

As we continue through this video, we see the skier demonstrating the Tony and Octo grabs. The Tony grab is a variation of the mute grab where the skier reaches down with their trailing hand to grab the toe edge of the ski on the opposite foot. This grab adds a unique twist to the basic mute, giving it a more stylish and personalized feel.

The Octo grab, on the other hand, is a more complex maneuver where the skier grabs both skis with both hands, creating an 'octopus' shape with their arms and skis. This grab requires excellent balance and control in the air, as well as flexibility to reach both skis simultaneously.

The skier in the video is executing these grabs with precision and confidence, showcasing the importance of practice and repetition in mastering these tricks. The use of trampolines for training is highlighted, allowing skiers to get numerous jumps in a short amount of time and experiment with different grab styles.

It's also worth noting that leading and trailing grabs have distinct differences in rotation and style, which can affect the overall look and feel of the trick. Skiers are encouraged to try both leading and trailing grabs to find what works best for them and to add variety to their repertoire.

Alright, so we're in the turtle position again. This is a great position for both offense and defense in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. As you can see, the person on top is controlling the bottom person's head with one arm while keeping their other arm free to either defend or attack.

Now, watch closely as the person on top transitions from the turtle position into an arm over guillotine choke. This is a very tight and dangerous submission if not defended properly. The key here is to keep the arm over the shoulder and the hand under the chin, applying pressure upwards.

As the choke deepens, the person on the bottom starts to defend by pushing against the choking arm, but it's too late. The person on top has already secured the anaconda choke, wrapping their arm around the neck and under the opposite armpit, creating a figure-four lock.

This is a very effective way to finish the fight if you're in the turtle position and can catch your opponent off guard. Remember to always train safely and with a partner who knows how to defend against these submissions.

Thanks for watching, guys. Don't forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more BJJ tutorials and tips. See you in the next video!

As we continue to explore the techniques for climbing in and out of the saddle, it's important to note that maintaining a smooth pedaling motion is key. When you're out of the saddle, try to keep your knees slightly bent to absorb any bumps or irregularities in the road. This will help you maintain a consistent rhythm and avoid losing momentum.

Another tip is to use your body weight to your advantage. As you push down with one leg, lean into the pedal stroke, allowing your body to naturally rock from side to side. This not only helps to generate more power but also keeps you balanced and stable on the bike.

When you're seated, focus on a higher cadence and lighter pressure on the pedals. This will help you conserve energy and make the most of your gear selection. Remember, the goal is to find a balance between efficiency and power, so experiment with different cadences and gear ratios to find what works best for you.

Lastly, don't forget to breathe and stay relaxed. Tension in your upper body can quickly drain your energy, so take deep breaths and keep your shoulders and arms loose. By combining these techniques with proper bike fit and gear selection, you'll be well on your way to becoming a master climber on the bike.

Alright, so we're looking at a person lying on their back with their knees bent and feet flat on the floor. This is a great stretch for the quadratus lumborum (QL) muscle, which can get tight from sitting or standing for long periods of time. By stretching this muscle, you can help alleviate lower back pain and tightness. It's important to hold the stretch for about 30 seconds on each side to really feel the benefits. Remember to breathe deeply and relax into the stretch for maximum effectiveness.

As we continue to explore the techniques for climbing in and out of the saddle, it's important to note that maintaining a smooth pedaling motion is key. When you're seated, try to keep your cadence high, around 80-90 revolutions per minute, as this will help you maintain momentum and reduce fatigue. When you stand up, your cadence will naturally decrease, but you should still aim for a consistent rhythm.

Another tip is to use your body weight to your advantage. When you're standing, lean forward slightly and put your weight over the pedals. This will help you generate more power and push through the tough sections of the climb. Remember to keep your knees slightly bent and your elbows locked, as this will give you stability and control.

It's also important to practice these techniques on different types of climbs. Try practicing on short, steep climbs as well as longer, more gradual ones. This will help you develop the strength and endurance you need to tackle any climb that comes your way.

Finally, don't forget to take breaks and rest when you need to. Climbing can be physically demanding, so make sure you're taking care of yourself and not pushing too hard. With practice and patience, you'll be able to master the art of climbing

The video continues with a demonstration of the HMS belaying technique, showing the climber's hands as they manipulate the rope and carabiner. The climber is seen forming a loop with the rope coming from the climber, an U, and then leading the rope around the back and over the fingertips to create a finished half-mast throw. The climber then clips the carabiner into the rope loop on their harness, ensuring that the brake cable runs along the healthy shank of the carabiner to prevent accidental opening due to rope friction.

The video also shows a second method for laying the HMS, known as the Mickey Mouse method. This involves forming two loops, or "ears," with the cable running in front and back, respectively. The climber then folds the two ears together, and the half-mast throw is finished. The climber clips the carabiner into the rope loop in front of their harness, again checking that the knot turns and the brake cable runs on the healthy thigh of the carabiner.

As we continue with Harald Harb's "How to ski" series, Lesson 3 delves deeper into the intricacies of executing advanced parallel turns. Harald emphasizes the importance of mastering the tipping action of the ski, which originates from the foot and ankle inside the boot. He demonstrates how this movement translates through the leg, creating a pivotal action that initiates the turn.

Harald clarifies a common misconception in skiing: the belief that pushing the knee out is the key to turning. Instead, he highlights that the true catalyst for the turn is the subtle yet powerful movement of the foot and ankle. This nuanced explanation underscores the precision required in skiing techniques.

The video captures Harald performing these movements at a direct angle, showcasing the fluid transition from one edge to the other. He explains that as the ski tips onto its edge, the knee follows naturally, but it's not the driver of the movement. The focus remains on the foot and ankle, which initiate the turn.

Moreover, Harald discusses the concept of lightening the ski during the turn. By leaving a little pressure on the tip of the ski, it aids in making the curve without applying excessive force. This technique allows for a smoother and more controlled turn.

Now, let's talk about the technique for delivering these powerful body shots. When you're preparing to throw a liver shot, you want to make sure your stance is correct. For a left-handed liver shot, your left foot should be forward, and you'll pivot on that foot as you rotate your body to generate power. Your right hand should be up to protect your face, and your left arm should be extended, with your fist making contact just below the opponent's ribcage on the right side.

For the spleen shot, it's similar but reversed if you're right-handed. Your right foot will be forward, and you'll pivot on that foot, rotating your body to deliver the punch with your right hand into the opponent's left side, just below the ribcage.

Remember, the key to these shots is the rotation of your body and the transfer of weight from your back foot to your front foot. It's crucial to keep your guard up and to follow through with your punch, bringing your hand back to its defensive position after making contact.

Alright, so I've got my shin across here. Now, the next thing I need to do is control his arm. I'm going to take this hand and put it on his shoulder. This is important because if he tries to pass, I can use this hand to stop him. And with my other hand, I'm going to grab his wrist. This way, I have control over both of his arms and can prevent him from passing my guard.

Now, let's talk about the footwork. My foot here needs to be flat on the ground for stability. And my other foot, I'm going to hook it behind his leg. This gives me leverage and makes it harder for him to move.

The key to maintaining this position is to keep my hips up and my weight distributed evenly. If I let my hips drop or my weight shift too much, he can easily pass my guard.

So, to summarize, the key basics for shin across half guard are: having your shin slightly over nine degrees, controlling his arm with your hand on his shoulder and grabbing his wrist, keeping your foot flat on the ground and hooking your other foot behind his leg, and maintaining proper hip position and weight distribution.

As we continue to watch this trial of the 2016 Tackle and Breakdown Law in NZ domestic competitions, we see a player in orange making a tackle on an opposing player in maroon. The player in orange has successfully brought the player in maroon to the ground, but now must release the ball immediately and get up or move away from it at once.

The breakdown midpoint is clearly visible as the point where the players are in contact, and the tackler must not play the ball from in front of this point. If the tackler does not release the ball or move away, they will be penalized for being offside.

We also notice that there is only one tackler in this situation, which means there is no breakdown or off-side line. This is an important distinction, as it changes the way the game is played and the strategies that teams can use.

Overall, this trial of the new tackle and breakdown law seems to be working well, with players adhering to the rules and the game flowing smoothly. It will be interesting to see how this law affects the game in the long run and whether it leads to any changes in player behavior or team tactics.

As we move into the next part of the workout, we have 30 seconds of single-leg bridge. Remember to focus on your core stability and engage your glutes as you lift one leg off the ground. After that, we'll do 30 seconds of single-leg bridge on the other side. It's important to maintain control and balance throughout this movement.

Following the single-leg bridges, we'll do 30 seconds of wall sits. Make sure to keep your back straight and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. This is a great opportunity to work on your lower body strength and endurance.

Next up, we have 30 seconds of burpees. Remember to keep your movements fluid and explosive. Try to get your chest and thighs to touch the ground on each rep, and make sure to jump over the barbell when you stand up.

After the burpees, we'll do 30 seconds of box jumps. Choose a height that challenges you but allows you to maintain good form. Remember to land softly on the box and step down carefully to avoid injury.

Finally, we'll finish the warm-up with 30 seconds of plank hold. Focus on keeping your core tight and your body in a straight line from head to heels.

Kevin is demonstrating the correct form for the One-Arm Dumbbell Row. He starts by placing one hand on a bench for support and gripping the dumbbell with his other hand. This is a crucial point for anyone looking to build a strong and impressive V-shape through rowing exercises.

As we continue through this video, we see the skier demonstrating the Tony and Octo grabs. The skier starts with a basic stance on the trampoline, then launches into the air to execute these advanced grabs.

The Tony grab is a variation of the mute grab where the skier grabs the toe edge of the ski with their opposite hand while crossing their legs. This grab requires good body control and flexibility. The skier in the video shows a smooth transition from the takeoff to the grab, maintaining a strong grip on the ski throughout the maneuver.

Moving on to the Octo grab, the skier demonstrates an impressive display of dexterity and balance. The Octo involves grabbing both skis simultaneously with both hands, crossing them in front of the body. This grab is visually striking and requires precise timing and coordination. The skier's execution of the Octo grab is fluid, showcasing their skill and confidence in performing complex aerial maneuvers.

Throughout the video, the skier's movements are crisp and deliberate, highlighting the importance of practice and technique in mastering these grabs. The use of the trampoline allows for repeated attempts and adjustments, which is crucial for perfecting such intricate tricks. The video serves as an excellent resource for skiers looking to enhance their repertoire of grabs

Welcome to the video titled "Tabata Songs"! In this video, we will be following along with a fitness routine that incorporates the Tabata workout method. As we continue with the "Rider Biomechanics Certification Programme," the instructor is demonstrating how to achieve proper seat bone positioning and its impact on the rider's posture. She explains that when a rider hollows their back, their seat bones point straight down, but when they round their back, the seat bones point in a different direction. This is crucial for maintaining balance and control while riding.

The instructor also addresses common misconceptions about thigh positioning, emphasizing that thighs should rotate inward and snug around the horse's side, creating an A-frame shape. This technique helps in maintaining the ideal hold on the horse.

She stresses the importance of transitioning from trying to doing, which involves entering a state of noticing mode. This means being fully present and aware of one's body position and movements, rather than just attempting the correct posture without full engagement.

The video concludes with a reminder that participants will need to submit photographs or videos at the end of each module for feedback, reinforcing the practical application of the concepts discussed.

As we continue to watch this video, we see the individual performing the paused bench press with a weight of 230 pounds for five sets of five repetitions. The focus on tricep strength development is evident in the narrower grip used by the lifter. The pauses at the bottom of each repetition are crucial for building strength and control, as they eliminate momentum and ensure that the muscles are doing all the work.

The lifter's form appears to be excellent, maintaining a tight body position throughout the movement. The pauses are held for two seconds, which is a challenging protocol that requires significant strength and discipline. The fact that the lifter was able to complete all five sets without struggling indicates a high level of conditioning and preparation.

It's worth noting that while the sets may have felt easy, the speed of the lift was lacking. This is a common phenomenon when incorporating pauses into a lift, as it increases the time under tension for the muscles involved. The reduced speed is a sign that the lifter is truly challenging themselves and working on building strength in a controlled manner.

Overall, this video showcases a dedicated approach to strength training, with a focus on specific muscle groups and techniques to improve overall performance. It's a great example of how athletes can use different variations of exercises

So, as he comes in with the single leg, I'm gonna use my hands to control his head and his posture. I'm gonna keep my feet wide and my weight low, so it's harder for him to lift me up. And then, as he tries to get a grip on my leg, I'm gonna use my other leg to push against his hip and create some distance. This is gonna make it harder for him to complete the takedown.

Now, if he does manage to get a good grip on my leg, I'm gonna use my hips to shift my weight and make it harder for him to lift me. I'm gonna try to sit back and put my weight on my other leg, while using my arms to push against his chest and create some space. And if all else fails, I'm gonna try to grab his arm and pull him down with me, so we're both on the ground and I can work from there.

Remember, the key to stopping a single leg takedown is to control your opponent's posture and create distance. Keep your feet wide, your weight low, and use your hips and arms to defend against the takedown.

He encourages practicing these movements slowly at first, gradually increasing speed as confidence and skill develop. By the end of this lesson, viewers should have a better understanding of how to execute an advanced parallel turn and be well on their way to becoming proficient skiers.

Finally, we have the twisting punch, which is a circular motion that adds power and speed to the strike. The twisting punch can be delivered with either the front or rear hand, depending on the situation.

In this video, we're going to talk about skateboard bearings and when you should consider changing them. We'll also share some tips and tricks to help you maintain your bearings and get the most out of your skateboarding experience.

First, let's talk about why bearings are important. Bearings are what allow your wheels to spin smoothly on your skateboard, giving you a faster and more efficient ride. Over time, bearings can wear out or get dirty, which can affect their performance.

So, how do you know when it's time to change your bearings? Here are a few signs to look out for:

1. Slowdown: If you notice that your skateboard is slowing down or not rolling as smoothly as it used to, it could be a sign that your bearings need to be changed.

2. Noise: If you hear any unusual noise coming from your wheels, such as grinding or clicking sounds, it could indicate that your bearings are worn out.

3. Age: Bearings have a limited lifespan, and if you've been using the same bearings for a long time, it might be time to replace them.

Now, let's talk about some tips and tricks to help you maintain your bearings:

1. Clean your bearings regularly: Dirt and debris can accumulate in your bearings and cause them

As we continue with Harald Harb's "How to ski" series, Lesson 3 delves deeper into the intricacies of executing advanced parallel turns. Harald emphasizes the importance of mastering the tipping action of the ski, which is initiated by the foot and ankle before the leg follows suit. He demonstrates this by pushing his ankle towards the outside of the boot, causing the ski to tip onto its edge, followed by the knee movement. Harald clarifies that the knee movement is a result of the tipping action and not the cause, dispelling common misconceptions about skiing techniques.

The video provides a clear visual representation of these movements, allowing viewers to understand the mechanics behind creating a parallel turn without pushing the skis away from the body. Harald's detailed explanation and demonstration offer valuable insights for skiers looking to improve their technique and achieve smoother, more controlled turns on the slopes.

Now, let's talk about the technique for delivering these powerful body shots. When you're preparing to throw a liver shot, you want to make sure your stance is correct. Your feet should be shoulder-width apart, with your lead foot slightly forward. As you throw the punch, rotate your hips and transfer your weight from the back foot to the front foot. Your arm should be extended fully, and your fist should make contact with the liver area just below the ribcage on the right side of the body.

For the spleen shot, it's similar but you'll be using your right hand if you're orthodox. You'll step to the left, rotating your body as you throw the punch. The key is to keep your guard up with your other hand to protect yourself from counterattacks. Remember, the power comes from your legs and hips, so make sure to use that momentum to your advantage.

When practicing these shots, it's important to focus on your form and follow-through. Don't just throw the punch and leave your arm hanging; bring it back to the guard position after making contact. Also, remember to breathe and not hold your breath while throwing the punches. Proper breathing will help you maintain energy and control throughout your workout.

As we continue to explore the intricacies of boxing's most impactful body shots, we're focusing on the liver shot and spleen shot. These punches are not just about power; they're about precision and timing. The liver shot, delivered with a left hook for a right-handed boxer, aims at the liver located under the right rib cage. When landed correctly, it can cause a unique reaction, almost like a groan or a gasp, as the boxer's body responds to the impact.

On the other hand, the spleen shot is executed with a right hook, targeting the spleen situated under the left rib cage. This punch can be equally debilitating, often leaving the opponent in a state of discomfort and disorientation. Both shots are designed to disrupt the rhythm and breath of the opponent, potentially leading to a knockout if the force is significant enough.

The key to executing these shots effectively lies in the setup. A good boxer will use feints and combinations to create an opening, then capitalize on the momentary lapse in defense to deliver the body blow. It's a testament to the skill and strategy involved in the sport of boxing, where every punch thrown has a purpose and every target is carefully considered.

Alright, so we're looking at a paused bench press set here. The individual is performing a 5x5 set with 230 pounds. Paused bench press is a technique used to build strength and control in the lift. Now, let's talk about the grip. The grip is very important for the forehand. You want to use a semi-western grip or an eastern grip. The semi-western grip is when you put your base knuckle on the third bevel of the racket handle. And the eastern grip is when you put your base knuckle on the second bevel. Both grips are good, but the semi-western grip gives you a little more topspin and power.

Next, let's talk about the stance. You want to have a slightly open stance with your feet shoulder-width apart. Your knees should be slightly bent, and your weight should be on the balls of your feet. This will give you stability and balance when you hit the ball.

Now, let's talk about the backswing. The backswing is when you take the racket back in preparation to hit the ball. You want to take the racket back early and smoothly. Your elbow should be bent at about a 90-degree angle, and your wrist should be relaxed. This will give you power and control when you hit the ball.

Now, let's talk about the grip. The most common grip for the forehand is the Eastern grip. You want to hold the racket with your base knuckle on the third bevel of the racket handle. This allows for a good balance between power and control.

Next, we need to focus on the stance. A semi-open stance is recommended for the forehand. This means that your feet should be shoulder-width apart with your back foot parallel to the baseline and your front foot pointing towards the net. This stance provides stability and allows for a smooth transition into the shot.

When it comes to the swing, remember to keep your eye on the ball and start your backswing early. Your non-dominant hand should be extended out in front of you, guiding the racket into position. As you swing forward, rotate your hips and shoulders, transferring your weight from your back foot to your front foot. Follow through with your racket, keeping your eyes on the target.

Finally, let's talk about timing. Timing is crucial for a successful forehand. You want to make contact with the ball when it's at its highest point in your reach. This ensures maximum power and control. Practice your timing by hitting balls tossed by a partner or using a ball machine.

As the video progresses, we see a series of tackles and breakdowns that illustrate the new laws being trialed in 2016 for NZ domestic competitions. The emphasis is on the tackle assist releasing immediately after the tackle occurs, ensuring that the game remains fluid and continuous.

Another clip shows a breakdown where players from both teams are contesting the ball on the ground. We can see that only players acting as halfbacks, who are not part of the breakdown and are behind the hindmost foot, are allowed to play the ball with their hands. This rule ensures that the game remains fair and that players are not at risk of injury from being tackled while on the ground.

Throughout the video, we see players adhering to the new laws, with the offside line being clearly marked by the back foot of the last player in the breakdown. As we watch this video, we see the skier demonstrating a shifty, which is an impressive aerial maneuver where the skier's upper body and lower body are rotated in opposite directions. This requires great control and balance to execute successfully.

The skier takes off from the ramp with their skis parallel to the ground, then in mid-air, they twist their body so that their upper body is facing one direction while their lower body and skis are facing the opposite direction. This creates a visually striking effect as if the skier is almost folded in half.

The key to performing a shifty is timing the rotation correctly and maintaining enough speed and height in the air to complete the maneuver before landing. The skier in the video does an excellent job of executing the shifty, showing good form and technique.

After completing the shifty, the skier then performs a zero spin, which involves rotating 360 degrees in the air without any additional twists or flips. The skier maintains a straight body position throughout the spin, keeping their skis parallel to the ground and their arms out for balance.

Overall, this video provides a great demonstration of two advanced skiing tricks, the shifty and the zero spin. It showcases the skill and athleticism required to perform these maneuvers

Vic Avery, our instructor, is demonstrating how to defend against this move. He's showing us that even when the opponent gets the initial advantage, there are still ways to counter and regain control.

As the opponent goes for the single leg, Vic quickly reacts by using his other leg to scissor around the opponent's waist. This technique is known as the popup leg scissor, and it's a great way to neutralize the takedown attempt while also setting up a potential counterattack.

Vic is emphasizing the importance of timing and body positioning. He's keeping his hips low and his weight distributed evenly, which allows him to generate enough force to execute the scissor motion effectively. This move is not only effective in wrestling but also in various grappling disciplines. It showcases Vic's expertise in chain wrestling, where the goal is to seamlessly transition between different techniques to keep the opponent guessing and off-balance.

Alright, so we're gonna continue with the single leg takedown defense. Now, let's say I'm in a situation where my opponent has managed to get a good grip on my leg and is attempting to lift me off the ground. My first priority is to maintain balance and control. I'll use my arms to frame against his body, keeping my elbows tight and my hands pushing against his chest or shoulders. This helps to create space and prevent him from getting a clean lift.

As he tries to lift, I'll shift my weight onto my other leg, using it as a pivot point. I'll also look to create an angle by stepping forward with my free leg, which can disrupt his momentum and make it harder for him to complete the takedown. It's important to keep my head up and eyes on him, maintaining awareness of his movements.

If he manages to get a good grip and starts to lift, I'll look to defend against the takedown by driving my hips forward and pushing against his body. I might also try to slip my leg out from under his grip, using the momentum to counterattack or regain my footing.

Remember, the key is to stay calm and focused, using technique and leverage to your advantage. Don't panic if you find yourself

Overall, the video provides a comprehensive guide to mastering the modified longstep versus RDLR guard, with clear instructions and demonstrations from Jeff Messina.
